Introduction

An omphalocele is a congenital abdominal wall defect characterized by herniation of abdominal viscera through an opening at the base of the umbilical cord; the herniated viscera is contained within a membranous sac with the umbilical cord at the apex (

figure 1
).

Pathophysiology and risk factors



At 4-8 weeks gestation, the midgut normally herniates through the umbilical ring because the embryonic abdominal cavity cannot accommodate rapid growth (

figure 2
).  The midgut then rotates counterclockwise before returning to the abdominal cavity by 12 weeks gestation.



Omphaloceles occur when the midgut fails to return to the abdominal cavity, resulting in abdominal viscera contained within a membranous sac composed of peritoneum and amnion at the umbilicus.



Omphaloceles have been associated with maternal risk factors, including extremes of maternal age (age >40 or <20), smoking, alcohol use, and obesity.



In addition, omphaloceles are associated with certain genetic conditions including:



  • Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome (
    figure 3
    )
  • Trisomy 13 (Patau syndrome)
  • Trisomy 18 (Edwards syndrome) 

Clinical presentation



Omphaloceles are typically detected during routine prenatal ultrasound after 12 weeks gestation.  At birth, omphaloceles appear as a mass at the base of the umbilical cord covered by a translucent membrane (

image 1
).  The defect may vary in size and contents (eg, intestines, liver, stomach).



Omphaloceles may be associated with other structural anomalies (eg, intestinal malrotation, cardiac defects, renal anomalies, pulmonary hypoplasia), suggesting an underlying genetic condition (eg, Beckwith Wiedemann syndrome) that warrants further testing.  Omphaloceles may also be associated with fetal growth restriction and polyhydramnios.

Diagnosis



Omphaloceles are often diagnosed upon visualization of a midline abdominal wall mass with the umbilical cord at the apex on routine prenatal ultrasound.  Additionally, alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) is produced by the fetal liver and gastrointestinal tract and absorbed into maternal circulation; therefore, maternal serum AFP is often elevated in cases of omphalocele (

).



Following diagnosis of an omphalocele, further evaluation may include:



  • Imaging (eg, fetal echocardiogram) to assess for associated structural anomalies
  • Laboratory testing (eg, microarray) for associated genetic conditions

Differential diagnosis



The differential diagnosis for omphalocele includes the following abdominal wall defects (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 2
):



  • Gastroschisis (
    figure 4
    ):  characterized by a full-thickness (ie, involving all layers of the abdominal wall) defect lateral to the umbilical cord site.  As a result, abdominal contents eviscerate through this opening.  Gastroschisis and omphalocele can be distinguished by the following:

    • Umbilicus involvement:  In gastroschisis, the abdominal wall defect is lateral to the umbilicus; therefore the umbilicus is unaffected and remains intact.  In omphalocele, the defect involves the umbilicus. 
    • Peritoneal membrane sac involvement:  Becasue gastroschisis involves a full-thickness abdominal wall defect, the abdominal viscera herniates into the amniotic cavity without a covering membrane.  In omphaloceles, the herniated abdominal viscera are covered by a peritoneal membrane.
    • Extraintestinal anomalies:  Gastroschisis tends to occur in isolation.  Omphaloceles are more likely to be associated with structural anomalies involving other organ systems (eg, cardiovascular, renal). 
  • Umbilical hernia (
    image 2
    ):  a benign, reducible protrusion of bowel through a fascial opening at the umbilical ring.  Although umbilical hernias are also midline, they are covered by skin, in contrast to omphaloceles. 

Management



Intrapartum management of omphaloceles includes close monitoring for fetal growth restriction via serial ultrasounds.  Unless otherwise indicated, term vaginal delivery is preferred, as there is no advantage to preterm delivery.  Cesarean delivery may be considered if the omphalocele is large.



Following delivery, immediate management is focused on stabilization, including addressing any associated structural anomalies.  Care must be taken to avoid clamping the umbilical sac containing intestines.  Additional management of omphaloceles after delivery includes:



  • Covering the defect in gauze soaked in warm sterile saline
  • Placement of the lower half of the infant's body in a sterile plastic bag to minimize insensible heat and fluid losses
  • Insertion of an orogastric or nasogastric tube to decompress the stomach
  • Stabilization of the airway
  • Initiation of intravenous fluids
  • Administration of empiric intravenous antibiotics that cover vaginal flora (eg, ampicillin, gentamicin) to reduce the risk of infection


Definitive treatment is surgical (ie, return of herniated bowel to abdominal cavity and closure of the abdominal wall defect).  Surgical repair is typically performed in a staged manner, with gradual reduction of the herniated bowel into the abdominal cavity, followed by closure.  The timing and approach to surgery depend on the size of the defect, the contents of the hernia sac, and the presence of associated anomalies.

Prognosis



The prognosis for infants with omphalocele depends on the size of the defect, the presence of associated anomalies, and the effectiveness of surgical management.  While many infants with isolated omphaloceles have a favorable outcome following surgical repair, those with complex omphalocele (eg, liver involvement) or significant associated anomalies (eg, pulmonary hypoplasia) have a poorer prognosis.



The recurrence risk of an isolated omphalocele in future pregnancies is low; those associated with genetic conditions (eg, Beckwith Wiedemann syndrome) have a greater risk of recurrence.

Summary



An omphalocele is a congenital abdominal wall defect characterized by herniation of abdominal viscera through an opening at the base of the umbilical cord; the herniated viscera is contained within a membranous sac with the umbilical cord at the apex.  The defect is typically diagnosed prenatally, and management is supportive (eg, close prenatal monitoring, limiting heat loss after birth) until definitive surgical repair can be performed.
